title: ‘Seagull’ Review: Blurring the Lines of Fiction
abstract: Elevator Repair Service’s Chekhov revival has promising ideas about art, experimentation and truth, but the production inevitably falls flat, our critic writes.
org_facet: Skirball Center for the Performing Arts

title: Comics That Read Top to Bottom Are Bringing in New Readers
abstract: The explosion of web comics has been driven by tapping into an audience the industry had long overlooked: young, female readers.
byline: By George Gene Gustines and Matt Stevens

title: The Ephemeral Art of Mexico City’s Food Stalls
abstract: In the heart of Mexico's capital, the colorful signs that have come to define the urban landscape of the city are being erased.

title: That Voice You’re Hearing? It Might Be Hers.
abstract: Julia Whelan is one of the most in-demand audiobook narrators working today. With her novel, “Thank You for Listening,” she’s telling a story of her own.

title: In ‘Uncoupled,’ Neil Patrick Harris Plays the Game
abstract: The actor described the Netflix comedy as an alternate vision of his life: “I got to live this other version of, what if I was single in New York and had a Grindr account?”

title: Conductor Dies After Collapsing During Performance in Munich
abstract: Stefan Soltesz was in the middle of Richard Strauss’s “The Silent Woman” when he fell from his podium shortly before the end of the first act.

multimedia.caption: Stefan Soltesz is the fourth conductor to collapse midperformance in Munich since the early 1900s.
Stefan Soltesz is the fourth conductor to collapse midperformance in Munich since the early 1900s.

title: ‘Nope,’ Eadweard Muybridge and the Story of ‘The Horse in Motion’
abstract: Is the rider in the 19th-century photographic experiments really unknown, as Jordan Peele’s film implies? It’s complicated.

multimedia.caption: Known as “Plate Number 626,” this Eadweard Muybridge study of a horse in motion is a key element of “Nope.”

title: Tom Sachs: Rocket Man to Renaissance Man
abstract: The artist is selling NFTs, designing Nikes, exploring outer space (sort of) and uncorking three concurrent shows in Seoul.

multimedia.caption: The artist Tom Sachs prepares a rocket for launch in Chicago in July. After 16 public launches in the last year, he is ending them, “so that we can focus on the next chapter, which is world-building.”

title: Review: A New Opera Tells an Original Story With an Open Heart
abstract: “Castor and Patience,” a work by Gregory Spears and Tracy K. Smith with an intense yet relaxed score, premieres at Cincinnati Opera.

multimedia.caption: Reginald Smith Jr. and Jennifer Johnson Cano in “Castor and Patience.” The opera’s vocal lines draw us close to characters in a rending situation: here, a Black family split by disagreement over whether to sell part of a precious plot of land.

title: Review: ‘The Kite Runner’ Trips From Page to Stage
abstract: Amir Arison stars as a guilt-ridden Afghan refugee brooding over a childhood friendship in a stiff adaptation of Khaled Hosseini’s best-selling novel.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: The heat wave in Europe, Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck’s big news, and President Biden’s coronavirus infection were among many topics the late-night hosts discussed this week.

title: A Novelist Says a Movie Fails to Credit Her. The Film World Shrugs.
abstract: Geling Yan says that she is owed a screen credit for the Chinese film “One Second” — and that companies bringing it to Western audiences are complicit in censoring her.

multimedia.caption: The writer Geling Yan has pushed for her novel “The Criminal Lu Yanshi” to be recognized in the film that it helped inspire.

title: Perry Rubenstein, Gallerist Convicted of Embezzlement, Dies at 68
abstract: He took his growing art business from Manhattan to Los Angeles, but it soon fell apart. Then, in 2016, he was arrested.

multimedia.caption: The gallerist Perry Rubenstein in 2007. He opened a gallery in Chelsea in 2004, then made waves seven years later when he announced that he was moving his operation to Los Angeles.

abstract: This vaudevillian show at La MaMa in Manhattan is like a party where weed is the guest of honor, thrown by ardent, uncritical hosts.

title: After Making a Splash in Manhattan, an Artist Gets His Due Back Home
abstract: The designer Stephen Sprouse, known for his Day-Glo jumpsuits and graffiti-infused formal wear, is the subject of a rock ’n’ roll-inspired showcase in Indiana, where he grew up.

multimedia.caption: Sprouse grafted a punk sensibility onto many his creations, including, top, a dress designed for Kate Moss to wear in MTV’s 1996 “Choose or Lose” voting campaign.

title: Young Sleuths Hot on the Trail of Their Own Identities
abstract: The protagonists of four new middle grade mysteries attempt to uncover secrets about their families and themselves.

title: Ronni Solbert, Children’s Book Illustrator, Dies at 96
abstract: She did the artwork for dozens of books, notably “The Pushcart War,” a parable about overcoming bullies, written by her partner, Jean Merrill.

multimedia.caption: Ronni Solbert in 1959: Her joyful illustrations helped make “The Pushcart War” a classic children’s book about peaceful resistance to injustice.

abstract: Ethan Hawke’s HBO Max documentary “The Last Movie Stars” examines two great actors in their own, and many of their friends’, words.

title: What’s in Our Queue? Music and More
abstract: I’m a senior editor in The Times’s Culture department. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

title: When ‘New Art’ Made New York the Culture Capital
abstract: Artists in the early 1960s drew from a heady mix: Mad magazine and Marilyn; the civil rights movement and the death of a president; queer bodies and “Pieta.” It’s all at the Jewish Museum.

multimedia.caption: “New York 1962-1964,” opening Friday at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan, from left: Roy Lichtenstein’s “Thinking of Him,” 1963; Marjorie Strider’s “Girl with Radish,” 1963; Rosalyn Drexler’s “Self-Portrait,” 1964.
multimedia.copyright: Rosalyn Drexler/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York; Lila Barth for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “New York 1962-1964,” opening Friday at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan, from left: Roy Lichtenstein’s “Thinking of Him,” 1963; Marjorie Strider’s “Girl with Radish,” 1963; Rosalyn Drexler’s “Self-Portrait,” 1964.
multimedia.copyright: Rosalyn Drexler/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York; Lila Barth for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “New York 1962-1964,” opening Friday at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan, from left: Roy Lichtenstein’s “Thinking of Him,” 1963; Marjorie Strider’s “Girl with Radish,” 1963; Rosalyn Drexler’s “Self-Portrait,” 1964.
multimedia.copyright: Rosalyn Drexler/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York; Lila Barth for The New York Times

title: To Illuminate History, an Artist Turns Out the Lights
abstract: At the New Museum, Kapwani Kiwanga explores light as a form of surveillance, from 18th-century “lantern laws” to the N.Y.P.D.’s 21st-century strategies.

multimedia.caption: Installation view of “Kapwani Kiwanga: Off-Grid” at the New Museum. “Cloak” at left works only with natural light, and was inspired by mobile police floodlights used in surveillance of low-income neighborhoods. Right, a 2019 sculpture “Maya-Bantu” is composed of metal rods covered in sisal and invokes aspects of a colonial past.

Installation view of “Kapwani Kiwanga: Off-Grid” at the New Museum. “Cloak” at left works only with natural light, and was inspired by mobile police floodlights used in surveillance of low-income neighborhoods. Right, a 2019 sculpture “Maya-Bantu” is composed of metal rods covered in sisal and invokes aspects of a colonial past.

Installation view of “Kapwani Kiwanga: Off-Grid” at the New Museum. “Cloak” at left works only with natural light, and was inspired by mobile police floodlights used in surveillance of low-income neighborhoods. Right, a 2019 sculpture “Maya-Bantu” is composed of metal rods covered in sisal and invokes aspects of a colonial past.
